intro: Gossypium hirsutum var. laciniatum, commonly known as the fringed cotton, is a variant of upland cotton characterized by its distinctive fringed or notched leaf margins. This plant is native to the Americas and is cultivated for its fibers, which are used in textile production. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and typically grows in warm climates with well-drained soil. The leaves are usually ovate to lanceolate in shape, and the flowers are typically pink or white. The plant is an annual herb that can reach heights of up to 1 meter, with hairy stems and hairy leaves.
